remarks.format: ## Remarks When a <xref:System.Web.UI.Control> instance is part of a control template, the TemplateControl property contains a reference to the containing control. For more information, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.TemplateControl?displayProperty=fullName> documentation.

Docs.summary: Gets the virtual directory of the or that contains the current server control.
Docs.value: The virtual directory of the page or user control that contains the server control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The TemplateSourceDirectory property specifies the path to the page or user control that contains the current control. For example, if the Web page resides at http://www.contoso.com/application/subdirectory, the TemplateSourceDirectory property returns "application/subdirectory".
To return the application-relative virtual path ("~/subdirectory"), use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.AppRelativeTemplateSourceDirectory%2A> property.
## Examples The following example uses the TemplateSourceDirectory property twice. The first time it is used in a <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.MapPathSecure%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method call to obtain the path to the directory in which the control resides. The second time it is in a <xref:System.IO.Directory.GetFiles%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method call to obtain the list of all the files contained within that directory.
[!code-cs[Control_TemplateSourceDirectory#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.control._10_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Control_TemplateSourceDirectory#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.control._10_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void TrackViewState() cil managed

Docs.summary: Causes tracking of view-state changes to the server control so they can be stored in the server control's object. This object is accessible through the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ViewState%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is called automatically at the end of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Init> event in the server control's lifecycle.
Invoke this method when you develop templated data-bound controls. This method alerts ASP.NET to monitor changes to a server control's view state, which is required when you override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.DataBind%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
## Examples The following example overrides the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.DataBind%2A> method in a custom ASP.NET server control. It begins by calling the base <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.OnDataBinding%2A> method and then uses the <xref:System.Web.UI.ControlCollection.Clear%2A> method to delete all the child controls and the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ClearChildViewState%2A> method to delete any saved view-state settings for those child controls. Finally, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ChildControlsCreated%2A> property is set to `true`. The control then uses the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.IsTrackingViewState%2A> property to determine whether view-state change tracking is enabled for the control. If it is not enabled, the TrackViewState method is called.
[!code-cs[Control_StateManagement#5](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.web.ui.control._9_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Control_StateManagement#5](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.web.ui.control._9_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets the unique, hierarchically qualified identifier for the server control.
Docs.value: The fully qualified identifier for the server control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property differs from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property, in that the UniqueID property includes the identifier for the server control's naming container. This identifier is generated automatically when a page request is processed.
This property is particularly important in differentiating server controls contained within a data-binding server control that repeats. The repeating control, which are <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Repeater>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataList>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsView>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.FormView>, and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> Web server controls (or any custom server controls that you create that include repeating functionality when data bound), serves as the naming container for its child controls. This means that it creates a unique namespace for its child controls so that their <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property values do not conflict.
For example, if you include an ASP.NET <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label> Web server control in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Repeater> server control, and assign the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label> control an <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property value of `MyLabel`, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Repeater> an <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> of `MyRepeater`. If you bind data to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Repeater> to an <xref:System.Collections.ArrayList> object with three entries, the resulting UniqueID properties for each instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label> server controls are `MyRepeater$ctl00$MyLabel`, `MyRepeater$ctl01$MyLabel`, and `MyRepeater$ctl02$MyLabel`.
## Examples The following example creates an <xref:System.Collections.ArrayList> object and populates it with three text strings, then binds a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Repeater> Web server control to the data in the <xref:System.Collections.ArrayList> when the page is loaded. The code gets the UniqueID property for each child control generated during data binding. The code generates three versions of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label> control and writes their `UniqueID` property values to the page.
[!code-vb[AccessingAspNetControlsProgramaticallyConcepts#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.control._11_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[AccessingAspNetControlsProgramaticallyConcepts#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.control._11_1.aspx)]

Docs.value: A value that determines whether the control checks client input. Values can include , , and . The default is , which means that the control gets the value from its parent.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For more information about request validation, see <xref:System.Web.UnvalidatedRequestValues>.

Docs.summary: Gets a dictionary of state information that allows you to save and restore the view state of a server control across multiple requests for the same page.
Docs.value: An instance of the class that contains the server control's view-state information.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A server control's view state is the accumulation of all its property values. In order to preserve these values across HTTP requests, ASP.NET server controls use this property, which is an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.StateBag> class, to store the property values. The values are then passed as a variable to an HTML hidden input element when subsequent requests are processed. For more information about saving server control view state, see [ASP.NET State Management Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
View state is enabled for all server controls by default, but there are circumstances in which you will want to disable it. For more information, see [ASP.NET Performance Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
For information about dictionaries and how to use them, see [Collections and Data Structures](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following example demonstrates implementing a `Text` property that stores and retrieves its value from its control's ViewState property.
[!code-vb[SysWebUIControlViewState#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.control._4_1.vb)] [!code-cs[SysWebUIControlViewState#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.control._4_1.cs)]

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the object is case-insensitive.
Docs.value: if the instance is case-insensitive; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Override this method if you create a custom server control that saves its view state without taking case into account. When you do so multiple objects with the same key, but with different casing, can be stored in the <xref:System.Web.UI.StateBag> associated with the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ViewState%2A> property.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to override the ViewStateIgnoresCase property to return `true`.
[!code-vb[System.Web.UI.Control_ViewStateIgnoresCase#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.control._2_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Web.UI.Control_ViewStateIgnoresCase#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.control._2_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual System.Web.UI.ViewStateMode ViewStateMode { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the view-state mode of this control.
Docs.value: The view-state mode of this control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use the ViewStateMode property to enable view state for an individual control even if view state is disabled for the page. For more information about view state and control state, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property.
To disable view state for a page and to enable it for a specific control on the page, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property of the page and the control to `true`, set the ViewStateMode property of the page to <xref:System.Web.UI.ViewStateMode>, and set the ViewStateMode property of the control to <xref:System.Web.UI.ViewStateMode>.
The default value of the ViewStateMode property for a page is <xref:System.Web.UI.ViewStateMode>. The default value of the ViewStateMode property for a Web server control in a page is <xref:System.Web.UI.ViewStateMode>. As a result, if you do not set this property at either the page or the control level, the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property determines view-state behavior.
The ViewStateMode property of a page or a control has an effect only if the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property is set to `true`. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property is set to `false`, view state will be turned off even if the ViewStateMode property is set to <xref:System.Web.UI.ViewStateMode>.

Docs.exception: An attempt was made to set this property to a value that is not in the enumeration.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool Visible { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether a server control is rendered as UI on the page.
Docs.value: if the control is visible on the page; otherwise .

remarks.format:
## Remarks If this property is `false`, the server control is not rendered. You should take this into account when organizing the layout of your page.
> [!NOTE] > If a container control is not rendered, any controls that it contains will not be rendered even if you set the Visible property of an individual control to `true`. In that case, the individual control returns `false` for the Visible property even if you have explicitly set it to `true`. (That is, if the `Visible` property of the parent control is set to `false`, the child control inherits that setting and the setting takes precedence over any local setting.)
